abstract: In making share buybacks, companies have a long record of buying high and selling low.
snippet: In making share buybacks, companies have a long record of buying high and selling low.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot investors cheered the company’s new stock repurchase plan, adding about $1.5 billion to its market value on Tuesday. History suggests they should curb some of their enthusiasm. American companies have a terrible track record of buying their own shares high and selling them low. Home Depot’s $1 billion program adds to the $136 billion of buybacks announced this year. Only the market peak of 2007 had more such activity. That’s not a good sign.

byline.original: By ROBERT CYRAN and CHRISTOPHER HUGHES
